title: Fairytale/Magic Wizzard type of font
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317102438im_/http:/typophile.com/files/HP%20Logo%20zonder%20krul%20achter%20elkaar_5491.jpg)

Note: the Character "H" and "P" are customized by the owner who gave me this file.

Font: 

 Edison Swirl SG 

Solved By: 

 [donshottype](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317102438/http:/typophile.com/user/205259 "View user profile.")

| --- | --- |
| [HP Logo zonder krul achter elkaar.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317102438/http:/typophile.com/files/HP%20Logo%20zonder%20krul%20achter%20elkaar.jpg) | 123.08 KB |
author: PauldC

comments.content: I have tried multiple websites where i was able to upload the image, but unfortunately with no results.

A prolific 19th century type designer named Hermann Ihlenburg may have been the originator of the style of using circular swirls to embellish a typeface, which was then sold as Houghton by ATF and later as Edison by Bauer and Berthold. See for example the revivals by Spiece Graphics as Edison Swirl [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/spiecegraphics/edison-swirl-sg/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317102438/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/spiecegraphics/edison-swirl-sg/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/spiecegraphics/edison-swirl-sg/") and by HiH as Edison [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/hihretrofonts/edison/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317102438/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/hihretrofonts/edison/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/hihretrofonts/edison/")  
The \_P\_ and \_H\_ in your image look like modified versions of the \_P\_ and \_H\_ in Houghton.  
Don

Many thanks! just what i needed. You're correct the "P" and the letter "H" are modified. I needed the font because one of my customers uses this font for a logo, but they never had any core files of the logo when it was designed back in te days.

So this helps me a lot! thanks.

You can probably lift the swirls from various parts of Edison and paste them on a simple set of lettering that matches the other letters.  
BTW this is not the first swirl font. Earlier ones include John cummings Kismet from 1879 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/kismet/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317102438/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/kismet/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/kismet/")  
Don
